utterances: First, we'll go to Capitol Hill, where Senate Democrats forced two votes today on extending the Bush-era tax cuts for everyone, but the wealthy.
NPR's David Welna joins us with the details.
It was entirely expected that these votes would fail.
One of them would have capped the amount of income eligible for tax cuts at a quarter million dollars a household; the other would have raised that cap to a million dollars per household.
But they both fell seven votes shy of the 60 they would have needed to advance.
A few Democrats joined every single Republican who voted in voting against the measures.
And Republican leader Mitch McConnell was pretty scornful of the whole exercise today.
Senator MITCH McCONNELL (Republican, Kentucky; Senate Minority Leader) Meaningless showboats and anti-business rhetoric won't do anything to make the situation better.
This Saturday's session is a total waste of the American people's time.
Yes, but New York Democrat Charles Schumer made it clear that these votes had another purpose.
They were also meant to portray Republicans as catering to the millionaires whose taxes would have gone up had these measures passed.

And over the next year when they come to the floor and talk about deficit reduction, they will be reminded that they chose $300 billion in tax breaks for the very wealthy, not paid for, increasing the deficit over any other priority.
Okay, David, but these tax cuts are scheduled to expire on December 31st.
So, what are the chances of this being dealt with before then?
Well, I don't think there's much of a chance that either Democrats or Republicans would allow them to expire at the end of the year.
Neither party wants to take the blame for taxes going up on January 1st.
And, in fact, today, President Obama called on lawmakers to work out a deal on taxes, as he said, in the next few days.

So it's looking highly likely that there will be probably a temporary extension of all the Bush-era tax cuts, and along with that an extension of lapsed unemployment benefits and probably a green light to go ahead with ratification of the START treaty as part of the deal.
NPR's David Welna on Capitol Hill.
Thanks, David.
You're welcome, Audie.
The tax cut debate is dwarfed by a bigger conversation about the deficit and the national debt.
And there's one thing members of Congress agree on: it's time to talk.
Unidentified Man #1: There's going to have to be a real - now, the term is an adult conversation.
Unidentified Man #2: Have an adult conversation.
Sit down and have a real discussion, an adult conversation.
Time for us as Americans to have an adult conversation with each other.
Unidentified Man #3: No yelling, no screaming.
Unidentified Man #4: We need to have an adult discussion.
Unidentified Man #5: Really an adult conversation.
Unidentified Man #6: An adult conversation about a very serious subject.
When the commission voted yesterday on its new proposal to reduce the deficit, only 11 members said yes.
Fourteen were needed to send a fast track plan to Congress.
Representative Jan Schakowsky, an Illinois Democrat, was one of the holdouts.
What I felt was that the way that we achieve deficit and debt reduction just gave too big a hit to the middle class.
I had offered my own proposal that would achieve primary budget balance, one of our assignments from the president, by 2015.
But I did it without further eroding the middle class in America.
So give us two recommendations that you disagreed with and why.
The cat's purr is a melodious snore.
Right.
It's a pretty weird-looking animal.
There's no question.
And that dentition - those tiny teeth out in the front of that spatula-like jaw, upper and lower jaw, is pretty wild-looking.
I don't...
Yeah.
I can't think of another dinosaur with a mouth that broad.
Although, some of the duck-billed dinosaurs have some pretty, the hadrosaurids, have some pretty weird jaws as well.
But it's a fascinating animal and, you know, it just underscores the point that we're finding new dinosaurs and new fossils all the time.
This was sort of a grazing, like a cow...
Yeah.
...a grazing dinosaur.
Yeah.
And I think this has been thought before.
There've been some studies that show that dinosaurs, certain of these long-neck sauropods couldn't raise their neck...
Mm-hmm.
...as high to, you know, crop foliage, to the treetop topiary that a lot of these paintings show, a lot of the reconstruction show.

And there's some ingenious computer reconstructions by various scientists that show these things are mainly grazing like cattle leave, you know, like cranes and grazing over ferns and grasses and such.
And this animal looks like it might have been doing the same.
It's amazing how you find these places in places you don't expect to find.
Yeah.
The dinosaurs.
Well, yeah, it's amazing.
The amount of discovery - the new discoveries of fossils and other dinosaurs seemed to be accelerating, not slowing down, in the - as we begin the 21st century.
Do you have any new digs you're on...
Well, I...
...exciting places you're looking at?
...I can't walk away from Mongolia.
We had our 18th season in Mongolia, in the Gobi Desert.
It's really one of the great treasure lands, dinosaur and other fossil hunting lands in the world.
And we did spend - we've been working some newer localities there in the eastern Gobi over the last couple of years.
They're really producing some very cool stuff.
So we're very, very excited about it.
Finding more eggs and bird-like features?
This set of units, not as many eggs as the other beds(ph) we have worked some years ago when we found the dinosaur embryos and the nesting dinosaurs.
But we're finding a lot of embryos of very small, juvenile dinosaurs in this site, and some different kinds.
And some of the mammals that are really fascinating, too.
There are new animals, so we're very happy.
People tend to forget that there may have been some mammals around at the same time.
Yeah, it's something I have to keep reminding them about because I'm very - I found a lot of dinosaurs, but I'm more fascinated in some of the mammals that got trampled underfoot.

And because for the very simple reason, those mammals, around that time, this is - we're talking about the end of the dinosaur age - they really foreshadow modern mammals, including ourselves, so they're very important from an evolutionary perspective.
Mm-hmm.
There's also a theory that's being brought up again this week about the possibility that it wasn't an asteroid or a giant body hitting the Earth that wiped out the dinosaurs, but volcanic activity.
Yeah.
I don't think people will ever stop arguing about the nature of the cretaceous extinction event and what caused it.
And again, we have this theory emerging or being proposed that these massive volcanic eruptions contributed more to the extinction event than other people would have it.
I've heard those theories offered before in different ways.
And of course, I'm still persuaded that the asteroid impact itself is - the timing is very close to the extinction event.
And also, you know, the scenarios about that are rather dramatic.
If something this size, bigger than Mount Everest, hits the Earth, it's going to cause a lot of problems.
I'm glad it had happened before, not now.

Talking with Michael Novacek, author of ""Terra: Our 100-Million-Year-Old Ecosystem--and the Threats That Now Put It at Risk."" As someone who's out there in the Gobi and other places, digging for the ancient history, I read the fear that you have in this book about the future.
